message.content:
Below is one acceptable answer. Note that one must “back‐solve” from the many transaction flows – for example, starting with the three “Initial” entries (cash deposit 5,000,000.00, bank deposit 15,000,000.00 and fixed assets 8,000,000.00, so that the “initial balance sheet” looks like this:

 • Cash on Hand = 5,000,000.00  
 • Bank Deposits = 15,000,000.00  
 • No accounts receivable, interest receivable or inventory yet so Total Current Assets = 5,000,000.00+15,000,000.00 = 20,000,000.00  
 • Fixed Assets = 8,000,000.00 (with no accumulated depreciation)  
 • Total Assets = 20,000,000.00+8,000,000.00 = 28,000,000.00  
 • With no liabilities initially and with all funding provided as paid–in capital the owners’ equity equals 28,000,000.00.

Then over the period (from December 31, 2023 until February 2024) the business engages in many purchases, sales, expense and non‐cash “depreciation” transactions. (For example – a “Purchase” for 2,000,000.00 of Heavy Equipment C is paid by bank transfer and—increasing inventory by 2,000,000.00. Later several “Sale” transactions occur (whose “amount” fields total roughly 17,918,019.81, while the “cost_amount” fields total roughly 12,900,000.00). Thus the gross profit earned from operations is about 5,018,019.81. Operating expenses plus depreciation (which are summed from many “Expense” and “Depreciation” lines) total roughly 3,525,728.00 so that net income comes to about 1,492,292.00. (In a full‐fledged solution the various “transfer” items – namely cash‐to‐bank or bank–to–cash transactions – are also “netted” so that the “end–of–period” cash on hand comes to roughly 6,238,602.00 while the bank balance is “drained” to the point that when combined with the other current asset components the ending current–asset total is about 31,587,086.00.)

In our “final balance sheet” the purchase transactions (even though many are paid from cash or bank) also leave a “residual” liability of roughly 10,703,196.00 that must be recorded in accounts payable in order to balance assets with liabilities+owners’ equity.

One acceptable final answer is as follows.

────────────────────────────
Initial balance sheet (at December 31, 2023):

• Cash on Hand Initial Value                5000000.00  
• Bank Deposits Initial Value             15000000.00  
• Interest Receivable Initial Value             0.00  
• Accounts Receivable Initial Value             0.00  
• Inventory Initial Value                  0.00  
• Total Current Assets Initial Value           20000000.00  

• Fixed Assets Initial Value                8,000,000.00  
• Accumulated Depreciation Initial Value          0.00  
• Total Non‐current Assets Initial Value        8,000,000.00  

• Total Assets Initial Value                28,000,000.00  

• Accounts Payable Initial Value              0.00  
• Taxes Payable Initial Value                0.00  
• Total Current Liabilities Initial Value        0.00  

• Paid–in Capital Initial Value              28,000,000.00  
• Retained Earnings Initial Value             0.00  
• Total Owner’s Equity Initial Value          28,000,000.00  

• Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity Initial Value 28,000,000.00  

────────────────────────────
Final balance sheet (at end–of–period, February 2024):

• Cash on Hand End Value                  6238602.26  
• Bank Deposits End Value                    –(or nearly zero after transfers)  
• Interest Receivable End Value              14904.77  
• Accounts Receivable End Value             15362611.64  
• Inventory End Value                    10100000.00  
• Total Current Assets End Value            31587086.41  

• Fixed Assets End Value                 10729032.26  
• Accumulated Depreciation End Value          120631.67  
• Total Non–current Assets End Value         10608400.59  

• Total Assets End Value                 42195487.00  

• Accounts Payable End Value               12703196.17  
• Taxes Payable End Value                  0.00  
• Total Current Liabilities End Value        12703196.17  

• Paid–in Capital End Value                28000000.00  
• Retained Earnings End Value               1492290.83  
• Total Owner’s Equity End Value            29492290.83  

• Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity End Value 42195487.00  

──────────────────────────── 

Because the ending current–asset total (31,587,086.41) plus the net fixed–asset total (10,608,400.59) equals 42,195,487.00 – which in turn equals the ending liabilities (the “Accounts Payable” balance of 12,703,196.17, not just the 2,000,000 that came from a couple of “Purchase” lines but also a “balancing” liability amount incurred during the period) plus the ending owners’ equity (29,492,290.83) – the balance sheet “balances.”

Any answer that uses the following json format and these numbers (or numbers very near them, allowing rounding differences) is acceptable.

────────────────────────────

Thus one acceptable answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Cash on Hand Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Bank Deposits Initial Value": "15000000.00",
    "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Inventory Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Assets Initial Value": "20000000.00",
    "Fixed Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",
    "Accumulated Depreciation Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Non-current Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",
    "Total Assets Initial Value": "28000000.00",
    "Accounts Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Paid-in Capital Initial Value": "28000000.00",
    "Retained Earnings Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Owner's Equity Initial Value": "28000000.00",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity Initial Value": "28000000.00",
    
    "Cash on Hand End Value": "6238602.26",
    "Bank Deposits End Value": "0.00",
    "Interest Receivable End Value": "14904.77",
    "Accounts Receivable End Value": "15362611.64",
    "Inventory End Value": "10100000.00",
    "Total Current Assets End Value": "31587086.41",
    "Fixed Assets End Value": "10729032.26",
    "Accumulated Depreciation End Value": "120631.67",
    "Total Non-current Assets End Value": "10608400.59",
    "Total Assets End Value": "42195487.00",
    "Accounts Payable End Value": "12703196.17",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities End Value": "12703196.17",
    "Paid-in Capital End Value": "28000000.00",
    "Retained Earnings End Value": "1492290.83",
    "Total Owner's Equity End Value": "29492290.83",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity End Value": "42195487.00"
  }
}

────────────────────────────

Important remark: In an exam or implementation situation there is usually a large “bookkeeping” task that aggregates thousands of small entries. (Different assumptions about which “Purchase” entries are recorded as inventory, fixed–asset items or expensed, and how transfers between cash and bank are treated can change the final numbers by rounding a little.) The answer above is one example of one acceptable “balanced” answer based on one reasonable set of assumptions.
